data: In the 1970s, the concept of ‚Äúmigraine art‚Äù was developed. It refers to the idea that visual art is an appropriate and sometimes the most suitable medium for expressing and communicating the unique experiences of migraine sufferers.

data.-disclaimer#‚ö†Ô∏è Disclaimer:
This tool is not a medical diagnosis and is intended for informational purposes only.
Neurological symptoms can have many different causes‚Äîsome of them serious. This tool assumes that your symptoms are not better explained by another medical condition, such as epilepsy, stroke, multiple sclerosis, or a known eye disorder.
If your symptoms are new, unusual, worsening, or occur alongside other health issues, please seek medical advice immediately.

data.introduction#Introduction:
You‚Äôll find the button to begin the symptom check at the bottom of this page‚Äîafter the disclaimer.
Introduction Migraine aura can take many forms‚Äîsome well known, others often overlooked.
The symptom check tool is designed to help you explore whether your symptoms align with the internationally recognized diagnostic criteria for migraine aura (ICHD-3).
At the Migraine Aura Foundation, we‚Äôve learned from over 7,000 patient accounts since 2000. While we adhere to current medical standards, we also recognize that science evolves‚Äîand we actively contribute to advancing how migraine aura is understood.
¬†

data.#: What were your aura symptoms like?

data.-you-meet-the--second-criterion#‚úÖ You:
‚úÖ You Meet The Second CriterionAt least three key characteristics of migraine aura are present.
Based on your responses, you display at least three of the hallmark features described in the internationally recognized diagnostic guidelines (ICHD-3). Our extensive data‚Äîgathered from over 7,000 patient accounts since 2000‚Äîsupports that these symptoms are common among those experiencing migraine aura.
While this result aligns with established criteria and our collective patient insights, please remember that this tool is for informational purposes only. It does not replace a formal medical evaluation. We encourage you to discuss these findings with your healthcare provider for personalized advice.
For more details on what each characteristic means and further guidance on managing migraine aura, please explore our additional resources or contact a professional.
View Full Report

data.-you-do-not-meet-the-second-criterion#‚ö:
‚ö†Ô∏è You Do Not Meet The Second CriterionFewer than three key characteristics apply.
Based on your answers, fewer than three of the key features associated with migraine aura are present. This suggests that your symptom profile does not fully align with Criterion C as defined by the ICHD-3 guidelines. However, not meeting this criterion does not rule out migraine aura‚Äîit simply reflects the diversity in symptom experiences.
If you continue to experience concerning symptoms or if your health situation changes, we strongly recommend consulting with a healthcare professional. Remember, our tool is designed to provide insights based on a broad patient base and is not a substitute for a medical diagnosis.
For further explanation and to learn more about how these criteria are applied, please review our detailed breakdown or speak with your doctor.
View Full Report

data.#:
Which aura symptoms have you experienced? We‚Äôre first checking for one or more fully reversible aura symptoms, as defined by clinical guidelines.
Aura symptoms affect different sensory or functional modalities ‚Äî such as vision, sensation, speech, or movement.
Please select all symptoms you‚Äôve experienced during your aura.
Choose ‚ÄúOther‚Äù if you‚Äôve had additional modalities not listed here.
Choose ‚ÄúNone‚Äù if none of these apply.
Modalities Visual ‚ìò Visual aura often includes flickering lights, zigzag lines, or blind spots. Sensory ‚ìò Sensory aura can cause tingling or numbness, usually starting in one hand and moving up the arm. Speech and/or language ‚ìò Speech aura can result in difficulty finding words or speaking clearly (dysphasia). Motor ‚ìò Motor aura can cause weakness or paralysis, typically on one side of the body. Brainstem (incl. dysarthria, vertigo, tinnitus, hypacusis, diplopia, among others) ‚ìò Brainstem aura includes vertigo, double vision, or unsteady gait without motor weakness. Retinal ‚ìò Retinal aura causes repeated attacks of visual disturbance in one eye (monocular). Other ‚ìò Other neurological symptoms not listed here but still reversible and aura-like. None Next

Check Other Modalities Clarifying Your ‚ÄúOther‚Äù Symptom Does the additional symptom you experienced resemble a known aura modality (e.g., visual, sensory, speech, motor, brainstem, or retinal)? Yes No

data.beyond-the-typical-visual-zigzags#Beyond:
Beyond the Typical Visual Zigzags Migraine aura isn‚Äôt only visual ‚Äî for some it is, but many experience effects on speech, sensation, or thinking.
Migraine aura isn‚Äôt always temporary ‚Äî conditions like visual snow syndrome can persist well beyond the typical episode.
Migraine aura isn‚Äôt always followed by a headache ‚Äî sometimes, the aura stands alone.

data:
While migraine is typically diagnosed through clinical history and the exclusion of other serious causes, the Migraine Aura Foundation highlights the unique diagnostic challenges posed by migraine aura. No blood test, imaging, or procedure can definitively confirm migraine‚Äîthough such tools may help rule out other conditions. The key remains in gathering a detailed history, supported by structured screening tools.
We advocate for refining this process, especially for aura, where early and accurate recognition possible with the help of digital biomarkers could transform both diagnosis and care.
Check your symptoms

data:
Since 2000, we collected thousands of patient reports of migraine with aura.
With encyclopaedic-worthy detail, we have sorted these reports into 20 basic aura types with over 30 aura subforms.
¬ªEvery patient with classical migraine opened out, as it were, into an entire encyclopaedia of neurology¬´ ‚Äì Oliver Sacks in his book Migraine.
